PM2.5 particles are tiny airborne particles with a diameter of 2.5 micrometers or smaller. 

 These can accumulate from various sources like cooking, cleaning products, and even outdoor air infiltration. 

 Due to their minuscule size, PM2.5 particles can penetrate deep into the lungs when inhaled and even enter the bloodstream. They have been proven to cause respiratory problems, aggravating existing lung conditions (such as asthma), and even contributing to cardiovascular issues.
Reference for the threshold values: "PM2.5 Explained", Indoor Air Hygiene Institute: https://www.indoorairhygiene.org/pm2-5-explained/
• Ensure proper ventilation while cooking and cleaning.\n • Dust and vacuum frequently.\n • Use air purifiers equipped with HEPA filters.

PM10 particles are airborne particles with a diameter of up to 10 micrometers. 

 They originate from sources such as dust, pollen, smoke, and vehicle emissions.

 Although larger than PM2.5, these particles still pose health risks since they’re small enough to penetrate the lungs. Upon inhalation, they impact the respiratory system and can end up causing breathing difficulties and aggravated asthma. These are specially important to monitor for people with dust or pollen allergies.

Reference for the threshold values: "PM10 and Air Quality: What is the Impact of Coarse Particles (Particulate Matter)", kaiterra: https://learn.kaiterra.com/en/air-academy/pm10-particulate-matter-pollutes-air-quality
• Regularly clean indoor surfaces.\n • Use a vacuum cleaner equipped with HEPA filters and damp mop floors.\n • Avoid smoking indoors.

Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC’s) are a group of chemicals that easily evaporate at room temperature such as Benzene, Formaldehyde and Toluene. 

 VOC’s are present in many household items and are emitted from many paints and varnishes as they dry, cleaning supplies, disinfectants, air fresheners and even furniture and building materials such as plywood, carpets, adhesives, and certain types of insulation.

 These chemicals can linger indoors and lead to adverse health effects upon prolonged exposure, including eye, nose, and throat irritation, headaches, and even damage to the liver, kidney, or central nervous system.
Reference for the threshold values: "Understanding VOC’s and its effects on health", uHoo: https://getuhoo.com/blog/home/understanding-vocs-and-its-effects-on-health/

• Choose paints, cleaning supplies, and furniture labelled as low VOC or VOC-free.\n • Ensure adequate ventilation by opening windows and using exhaust fans while painting, varnishing, or using cleaning products.\n • Consider Indoor Plants, such as peace lilies or spider plants, since they can assist in absorbing VOC’s.

Carbon Monoxide (CO) is a colorless, odorless gas produced incomplete combustion of by carbon-containing fuels.

 It’s emitted by malfunctioning or poorly maintained heating systems (like furnaces, boilers, water heaters), stoves, fireplaces, generators, and vehicle exhausts.

 CO is a significant concern because it binds to hemoglobin in red blood cells more readily than oxygen does. This prevents the blood from carrying oxygen effectively, leading to CO poisoning. Symptoms of CO exposure include headaches, dizziness, nausea, confusion, and in severe cases, unconsciousness, or death.
Reference for the threshold values: "Carbon Monoxide Levels Chart", CO2Meter: https://www.co2meter.com/blogs/news/carbon-monoxide-levels-chart

• Ensure proper airflow by opening windows or using ventilation systems.\n • Minimize activities such as burning candles or using gas stoves without proper ventilation.\n • Opt for electric appliances or those that produce fewer emissions.
